newsitem.title: FINLAND: Nokia sees data soaring in cellular.
newsitem.headline: Nokia sees data soaring in cellular.

text.p: Finnish telecoms group Nokia Oy expects data transfer to surge to 50 percent of traffic in cellular networks by 2000 from around five percent now, a Nokia official said on Wednesday.
"Data traffic in cellular networks is expected to rise from five percent to 50 percent in 2000," Nokia marketing communications manager Mika Setala told a briefing.
Although he said the estimate seemed very high, he added that Nokia had "good reasons to believe that it is so".

Nokia -- in 1994 the first company to introduce the link between personal computers and digital mobile phones now known as a PCMCIA card (Personal Computer Memory Card International Association) -- was presenting its work developing systems for compressing multimedia data for transfer in cellular networks.
